title: Meet and Eat
description: Time to kick off camp! Join us for some snacks and getting to know your fellow campers!

title: Pop-up books and paper circuits
description: Pop-up engineering is really fun and extremely satisfying – for adults and for kids. But how might we use electricity to change the idea of what “interactive” books can be? In this session, participants will create pop-up cards that use the affordances of our materials to really investigate how circuits can change the idea of what a book can be. We’ll also consider where soft circuits are going by looking at examples in toys and wearable technologies.

title: Creative Coding with Processing
description: This workshop will give you an introduction to the basic principles of creative coding with Processing. Processing is an open-source coding platform used by designers and developers to create interactive installations, data visualizations, software tools, and much much more.

title: Introduction to User Experience (UX)
description: What is User Experience?

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium
description: Mobile Storytelling as a New Medium is the first installment of a 3 part series on creating narratives within in the framework of a app. This lecture is a survey of current artists and projects using the mobile platform to create innovative narrative forms (i.e: Christoph Niemann’s “Petting Zoo”,  David Benqué’s “The Infinite Adventure Machine”, Works from “Les Editions Volumiques” etc…).

title: Introduction to Soft Circuits
description: In this class, we will go over conductive materials used in creating soft circuits, such as different thread, fabrics, inks and fasteners, along with looking at microcontrollers designed specifically for wearable electronics. Projects that have been created utilizing these techniques will also be shown. We will then create a simple soft circuit with a switch and that lights up a LED. Attendees will have the chance to learn or expand on basic hand sewing techniques and experience working with new materials and skills.

title: Early version – From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Advanced, earlier date of my presentation on the 17th for those of you who wish to get ideas for your Camp projects a little sooner.

title: iOS Boot Camp
description: Getting started with the iPhone, iPad or iPod touch using Apple’s native development tools. This is a three hour hands on workshop session that should get you beyond the “Hello World” stage and leave you with code running on you device and on to the interesting stuff. We’ll hopefully move on to playing around with the onboard sensors, or perhaps the map and location frameworks, depending on what people in the class would rather do with the time.

title: Intro to the Soft Lab
description: This workshop will introduce you to the basics of using ITP’s soft lab resources — specifically the sewing machines, the embroidery machine, and the vinyl cutter.  This will mostly be a demo session, so no materials are required!

title: Hello PhoneGap
description: The miracle of mobile computing has arrived. Exceedingly powerful computers, seamlessly networked and with a variety of in-built sensors… all right in your pocket.PhoneGap is an open source framework that lets you program cross-platform mobile phone apps using HTML, Javascript and CSS. Providing a Javascript API to access  the accelerometer, GPS, notifications, and other hardware capabilities of your phone, you can write your code once and deploy the app to Android, iPhone, Blackberry and several other platforms.

title: Wearables Hack Day
description: Do you sew? Do you play with microcontrollers? Then join us for ITP Camp wearables hack day!

title: Conductive Lace Making
description: Crochet, knitting, bobbin lace — join this session if you want to explore possibilities of lace as conductive material and if you want to learn basics of lacemaking.

title: Build a music visualizer from scratch in Processing
description: So!  Sunday night, after you’ve hacked some wearables, get down and dirty with an excellent intermediate level processing session on crafting a music visualizer.  I find it’s easiest to learn how to do something new when you have a project to try it with, so lets make a music visualizer!

title: Introduction to HTML / CSS
description: Part 2 of 3 in a series of sessions that provide a framework for creating narratives in the form of mobile apps.

title: C4 – Media, Interactivity & Audio for iOS
C4 – Media, Interactivity & Audio for iOS
Simple Animations for Digital Narratives
description: Part 3 of 3 in a series of sessions that provide a framework for creating narratives in the form of mobile apps.

title: C4 – Media, Interactivity & Audio for iOS
OpenNI Kinect with Osculator, Max/Jitter, Processing, Ableton Live etc
description: 10am – 12 (some calendars are showing 11am for some reason)

title: Crazy Data Circles with d3.js
ITP Mappathon: Projection Mapping with MadMapper
description:
Step 2
 This week, we will learn how to connect your visual content created from Modul8 to a projection mapping software, MadMapper.

title: Re-wiring for Re-cycling
description: Physical Computing strikes me as a unique opportunity to recycle materials destined for landfill while creating unique objects and experiences. I’ve recently come to realize that a large part of my increased comfort level with electronics derives from a shift in perspective; no longer do I simply see a lonely rusted bike wheel littering my neighborhood, but raw materials such as spokes that make great axles for rotating propellers and mirrors. The VCR I found outside my friend’s studio became a drawer of motors, buttons, and a tape reader that now scans discarded video tapes in tandem with that bike tire! So for this session I’d like to lead a conceptual and hands on workshop in which we dream up ways to use discarded electronics (which I will provide). What inventive ways will we think to use an air mattress pump? A robotic aerosol sprayer? A game involving a levitating object? The possibilities are vast and can only improve with a conceptual shift concerning everyday objects.

title: Intro to PhoneGap and NFC
description: So you already went to Sean Montgomery’s session, “Hello PhoneGap” last week, or maybe you didn’t.  But you know what HTML is, and you know a little JavaScript, and you’re thinking, “Gee, I wish I could develop mobile apps that use Near Field Communication on Android!”  Yep, this session is for you.

title: Arduino 101
description: Learn the very basics of how to program with the popular platform for physical computing projects. If you took the “Hello, Arduino” session on Monday night, this session will cover that information, but also delve deeper into the topics of digital input and output as well as analog input and output.

title: Arduino Programming Basics
description: So if you want to move beyond the blinking LED and learn some more coding for the Arduino, this is the class for you. We’ll review some of the coding from Arduino 101 and then move onto variables, for loops, while loops, and writing your own functions.

title: UX Skill – Responsive Design Process
description: Do you create UX documents in Omnigraffle, Visio, InDesign, Axure or Illustrator?  Does the design team still create Photoshop PSD files to hand off to the developer?  That no longer works in the responsive design world we live in.

title: Intro to Scratch (and Makey Makey)
description: Scratch is a free program geared towards teaching kids introductory programming skills through gamemaking and animation. It can be paired easily with the Makey Makey, an extremely easy-to-use microcontroller that can turn anything into a keyboard. Come check it out!

title: TinkerCAD – 3D Design for Toddlers
description: This is the easiest 3D design program out there. I use it to teach 3D design and printing to toddlers. Seriously.

title: 3D Scanning Workshop with the Kinect & ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models. I have built a rig for doing full body human scans. The rig builds on this turntable I built last year: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28454 We’ll cover my scanning technique then a workflow for taking scans to a printable mesh using Netfabb Basic. I can also touch on some tricks with Meshlab if we need to combine meshes, remesh or reduce polygon count.

title: Intro to Soft Circuits round 2
description: Did you miss the Intro to Soft Circuits workshop?

title: Wearable Computers
description: attending
comment: Attending. Does anyone know where I can buy the Lilypad? The NYU store is closed on Saturday. I am not sure if I can make it there before they close today as I work in central NJ.

title: From Story to Tech: a methodology project
description: Often times, it seems that tech projects can come off as nothing more than technological masturbation. Many of us know what it’s like to witness a new project with cutting-edge tech only to feel disappointed, likening the experience more to a technical demo than something poignant and worth remembering. This may happen with projects of any nature, of course, but tech projects are especially prone to the pitfall of gadgetry taking precedence over meaning.

title: Now What?! How to turn your prototype into a product
description: When individuals and companies want to bring their product to the market, they run into hurdles like how to source materials, how to access a group of people who will buy it, and how to do it in a way that it doesn’t eat up all their savings and free time. This session is a crash course in the commercialization arc that includes product development, validation, and commercial ramp up.  Issues that arise in these post-prototype stages are important design insights that will make your product idea stronger. We’ll get into practical examples of how to connect with funding sources, user communities, and manufacturers while sharing resources that’ll be ready and waiting once camp is over.

title: Jitter Workshop: Coding for Video Art
Faster Fashion – Rapid Prototyping and the Things We Wear
Physics Simulations in Processing
description: This workshop will give a condensed overview of various kinds of physics simulations in Processing. We’ll go over oscillation, a basic Particle class, attraction and repulsion forces, collision detection, and an introduction to the Box2d library, the physics engine behind a little game you might’ve heard of by the name of Angry Birds.

title: Flying Robots
description: There is a growing community interested in building flying autonomous robots.   We will go over the history of flying robots.  The current and future roles these robots will play in our society.

title: VJ – Syphon / VDMX / Jitter / TouchOSC
description: Another quick introduction to VJ software! Of course many of the things we’ll discuss are applicable to the larger world of visual art. Topics include Syphon, a nifty library that allows you to create a video wormhole from one application to another; TouchOSC, the touch interface that lets you adjust virtual knobs which you can use to control variables in Max, VDMX, etc.; and using the Kinect to create a depth map video mask.

title: Hacking the Kinect skeleton into Processing – follow- up
description: This is an informal follow-up to the OpenNI in Osculator, Max Jitter Ableton class.

title: Face It
description: In this short workshop, we will examine the human face. We’ll look at the differences between face detection and face recognition as well as demonstrate examples that track the contours of the face. In addition, we’ll look at some image processing techniques for face morphing. Examples will be demonstrated in Processing.

title: Guest Speaker: Andrew Dent from Material ConneXion
description: Andrew Dent will be joining us to discuss what’s happening with materials and what’s soon to come.

title: Intro to openFrameworks, part 2
description: Part 2 will cover:

title: Zero to Plastic Part 1: Using SketchUp to design for 3D Printing
description: Your host the Great Fredini will go through the basics of 3D design in SketchUp. We’ll cover Sketch up’s basic tools and the use of digital calipers to design a 3D object based on real world measurements. Once parts are designed, we will export them as STL files and prep them for 3D printing with Netfabb Basic and slice the file with Makerware for printing on the ITP Makerbot.

title: Zero to Plastic Part 2: 3D Scanning with ReconstructMe
description: We’ll explore 3D scanning using an Xbox Kinect controller with ReconstructMe software, and the steps needed to convert these scans to 3D printable models.

title: Beat Making for Babies
description: Beat Making for Babies is a fool proof introduction to making music with your computer. We’ll cover the basics of how to make simple beats using Midi, crafting beats from original & found sounds, and the seeds of combining our beats with emerging technologies.

title: Introduction to Rhino
description: Thank you for signing up, I’m looking forward to meeting you all.

title: Nudgeables Workshop
description: Sometimes we use secret codes to communicate with our friends, partners, or colleagues while in the company of a larger group of people: a nudge, a cough, a scratch of the nose; something that says “I’m thinking of you…”, “Save me from this conversation!”, or “Let’s get out of here!”.  What if our clothing could communicate these messages for us?

title: Learn vim
description: Attention campers!  Anyone wanna learn vim?

title: Visual Effects and Compositing using After Effects
description: In this workshop we’ll look at using After Effects for visual effects and compositing, including green screen and motion tracking.

title: Midi, Sysex, and the Arduino. New tricks for an old dog.
description: unable to attend this day but would love to get notes on this afterwards if anyone can share

title: Building + sculpting in Second Life (workshop session 2 of 2)
description: You know the SL basics or just attended the 4pm session.

title: Making Fireworks in Three.js
description: Make a neat fireworks animation just in time for the Fourth of July!

title: Tom Igoe Mystery Talk
Collaborative Mobile Design for International Development
description: The world has nearly as many cell phone subscriptions as inhabitants, and 75% of them are in the developing world, with Africa leading the way. As the majority of mobile phone users live in emerging markets and developing economies, how do we design collaboratively with their needs, cultures and dreams in mind? How can mobile phone apps change informal economies and what goes into design considerations? How can we work together to improve billions of lives?

title: Designing Projections for a Chamber Opera
description: I recently created video projections for “Lotus Lives,” a new independent one-hour opera written for two singers, a brass quintet, percussion, and audio-video playback. I tackled everything from content design and creation, through coordinating six projectors with a live performance on a limited budget, and making sure it ran smoothly.

title: Mobile Culture: How leading startups create and unleash mobile behavior
description: Learn how 3 top startups create mobile experiences around specific user groups, tapping into existing behavior and unleashing new one.

title: Prototyping Interactive Spaces with Spacebrew
description: Spacebrew is a service (and software toolkit) that was built for prototyping interactive spaces and internet of things objects. It makes it easy to connect applications and interactive objects by supporting a wide selection of languages and platforms.

title: Building Websites with Twitter Bootstrap
description: Hi! This is a hands-on workshop where we are going to build a single page portfolio site with Twitter Bootstrap.

title: End-of-Camp Shindig
description: Half show & tell, half party, the End of Camp Shindig is an opportunity to celebrate the month we’ve spent together and share what we’ve created.
